message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Schematic Bases of Social Information Processing
Paper Abstract: The term, schema, appears to have been first used by Bartlett in 1932 in his work on recall of perceptual experience. A minimal theory is not, however, necessarily a good theory, and so one may want to inquire of the schema's literature not only if the minimum criterion of a theory has been met, but if it is a good theory. When a stimulus configuration is encountered in the environment, it is matched against a schema, and the ordering and relations among the elements of the schema are imposed on the elements of the stimulus configuration. Studies comparing the effects of memory set versus impression set on recall also point to the structuring function of schemas. Information is easier to recall, however, if it is structured in some way, and there is evidence that people will structure stimuli so as to facilitate recall. Default options may not only be inserted when a particular piece of data is missing.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Frederic Bartlett:

## Overview

Sir Frederic Charles Bartlett FRS (20 October 1886 – 30 September 1969) was a British psychologist and the first professor of experimental psychology at the University of Cambridge.(no content)He was one of the forerunners of cognitive psychology as well as cultural psychology.

## Major Contributions

### Schema Theory

Frederic Bartlett was one of the first psychologists to propose Schematic theory, suggesting that the individual's understanding of the world is influenced by elaborate neural networks that organize abstract information and concepts.(no content)This concept was first described in the works of British psychologist Frederic Bartlett, who drew on the term body schema used by neurologist Henry Head in 1932.

### Reconstructive Memory

Bartlett was the Chair of Experimental Psychology at Cambridge when he published the book he is most famously recognised for: Remembering (1932).(no content)The "War of the Ghosts" experiment from Remembering (1932) was Bartlett's most famous study and demonstrated the reconstructive nature of memory, and how it can be influenced by the subject's own schema.

### Applied Psychology

He and Kenneth Craik were responsible for setting up the Medical Research Council's Applied Psychology Research Unit (APU) at Cambridge in 1944, where they worked with experimental psychologist Magdalen Dorothea Vernon. Bartlett became the Director of the Unit after Craik's early death in 1945.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about information processing psychology:

## Overview

In cognitive psychology, information processing is an approach to the goal of understanding human thinking that treats cognition as essentially computational in nature, with the mind being the software and the brain being the hardware.(no content)It arose in the 1940s and 1950s, after World War II.

## Core Theory

The theory is based on the idea that humans process the information they receive, rather than merely responding to stimuli, and uses an analogy to consider how the mind works like a computer.(no content)According to the standard information-processing model for mental development, the mind's machinery includes attention mechanisms for bringing information in, working memory for actively manipulating information, and long-term memory for passively holding information so that it can be used in the future.

## Key Components

Cognitive processes include perception, recognition, imagining, remembering, thinking, judging, reasoning, problem solving, conceptualizing, and planning. These cognitive processes can emerge from human language, thought, imagery, and symbols.

## Historical Significance

Information-processing models helped reestablish mental processes—processes that cannot be directly observed—as a legitimate area of scientific research.(no content)According to the Atkinson-Shiffrin memory model or multi-store model, for information to be firmly implanted in memory it must pass through three stages of mental processing: sensory memory, short-term memory, and long-term memory.

I've completed the web search for "Schema psychology cognitive." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

In psychology and cognitive science, a schema describes a pattern of thought or behavior that organizes categories of information and the relationships among them.(no content)It can also be described as a mental structure of preconceived ideas, a framework representing some aspect of the world, or a system of organizing and perceiving new information.

## How Schemas Work

Schemata influence attention and the absorption of new knowledge: people are more likely to notice things that fit into their schema, while re-interpreting contradictions to the schema as exceptions or distorting them to fit.(no content)People can organize new perceptions into schemata quickly as most situations do not require complex thought when using schema, since automatic thought is all that is required.

## Historical Development

Early developments of the idea in psychology emerged with the gestalt psychologists and Jean Piaget, who introduced the term schéma in 1923.

## Types of Schemas

The search results revealed several specific types:
- **Self-schemas**: A long lasting and stable set of memories that summarize a person's beliefs, experiences and generalizations about the self, in specific behavioral domains.
- **Cultural schemas**: A cognitive theory that explains how people organize and process information about events and objects in their cultural environment.
- **Image schemas**: A recurring structure within our cognitive processes which establishes patterns of understanding and reasoning.

The search results provide comprehensive information on this fundamental cognitive psychology concept and its various applications.

I've completed the web search for "Schema psychology cognitive." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

In psychology and cognitive science, a schema describes a pattern of thought or behavior that organizes categories of information and the relationships among them.(no content)It can also be described as a mental structure of preconceived ideas, a framework representing some aspect of the world, or a system of organizing and perceiving new information.

## How Schemas Work

Schemata influence attention and the absorption of new knowledge: people are more likely to notice things that fit into their schema, while re-interpreting contradictions to the schema as exceptions or distorting them to fit.(no content)People can organize new perceptions into schemata quickly as most situations do not require complex thought when using schema, since automatic thought is all that is required.

## Historical Development

Early developments of the idea in psychology emerged with the gestalt psychologists and Jean Piaget, who introduced the term schéma in 1923.

## Types of Schemas

The search results revealed several specific types:
- **Self-schemas**: A long lasting and stable set of memories that summarize a person's beliefs, experiences and generalizations about the self, in specific behavioral domains.
- **Cultural schemas**: A cognitive theory that explains how people organize and process information about events and objects in their cultural environment.
- **Image schemas**: A recurring structure within our cognitive processes which establishes patterns of understanding and reasoning.

The search results provide comprehensive information on this fundamental cognitive psychology concept and its various applications.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Recall memory cognition"

Links: [{"title":"Recall (memory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_(memory)"},{"title":"Recall test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_test"},{"title":"Free recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_recall"},{"title":"Recognition memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recognition_memory"},{"title":"Memory improvement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_improvement"},{"title":"Memory rehearsal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_rehearsal"},{"title":"Eidetic memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidetic_memory"},{"title":"Recognition failure of recallable words - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recognition_failure_of_recallable_words"},{"title":"Short-term memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-term_memory"},{"title":"List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_memory_biases"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about recall memory and cognition:

## What is Recall Memory?

In cognitive psychology, a recall test is a test of memory of mind in which participants are presented with stimuli and then, after a delay, are asked to remember as many of the stimuli as possible.(no content)Recall is also involved when a person is asked to recollect life events, such as graduating high school, or to recall facts they have learned, such as the capital of Florida.

## Types of Recall

There are different forms of recall testing:

- **Free Recall**: Free recall is a common task in the psychological study of memory. In this task, participants study a list of items on each trial, and then are prompted to recall the items in any order.

- **Cued Recall**: A cued recall test is a procedure for testing memory in which a participant is presented with cues, such as words or phrases, to aid recall of previously experienced stimuli. Research shows that retrieval cues aid memory. Participants in the free recall group recalled 40 percent of the words, whereas participants in the cued recall group recalled 75 percent of the words.

## Factors Affecting Recall

Several cognitive principles influence how well we recall information:

- **Encoding Specificity**: The participants demonstrated a better recall when the context of retrieval matched the context of encoding, for example having studied underwater and being tested underwater.

- **Depth of Processing**: Craik and Tulving discovered that the words that required deeper processing were remembered best.

- **Memory Rehearsal Types**: In 1972, Craik and Lockhart proposed that memory recall involves multiple processes operating at different levels. Maintenance rehearsal involves repeatedly processing an item at the same level, which requires little attention. It has the potential to improve immediate recall, but has little effect in recall in long-term memory.

Web search results for query: "Memory psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory"},{"title":"Associative memory (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associative_memory_(psychology)"},{"title":"Methods used to study memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methods_used_to_study_memory"},{"title":"External memory (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/External_memory_(psychology)"},{"title":"Working memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_memory"},{"title":"Cognitive psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology"},{"title":"Episodic memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Episodic_memory"},{"title":"Genetic memory (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_memory_(psychology)"},{"title":"Storage (memory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storage_(memory)"},{"title":"Procedural memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procedural_memory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of memory psychology:

## Definition and Core Functions

Memory is the faculty of the mind by which data or information is encoded, stored, and retrieved when needed, serving as the retention of information over time for the purpose of influencing future action.

## Memory Systems

Memory is often understood as an informational processing system with explicit and implicit functioning that is made up of a sensory processor, short-term (or working) memory, and long-term memory.

### Working Memory
Working memory is a cognitive system with a limited capacity that can hold information temporarily and is important for reasoning and the guidance of decision-making and behavior.

### Long-Term Memory Categories
Modern conceptions of memory break down long-term memory into three main sub-classes, including procedural memory, which is memory for the performance of particular types of action and includes stimulus-response-type information.(no content)Episodic memory is the memory of everyday events (such as times, location geography, associated emotions, and other contextual information) that can be explicitly stated or conjured, representing the collection of past personal experiences that occurred at particular times and places.

## Memory Types: Retrospective vs. Prospective

Another major way to distinguish different memory functions is whether the content to be remembered is in the past, retrospective memory, or in the future, prospective memory.

## Field Context

Cognitive psychology is the scientific study of human mental processes such as attention, language use, memory, perception, problem solving, creativity, and reasoning.

Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Triples Extracted and Validated:**

1. **Schema (psychology)** - Concept (uses)
   - Core framework for understanding how individuals organize information about the world and process new stimuli

2. **Memory** - Concept (uses)
   - Fundamental mechanism underlying schema-based information processing and recall of perceptual experiences

3. **Recall (memory)** - Task (uses)
   - Primary task studied to understand how schemas facilitate or structure the retrieval of stored information

4. **Information processing (psychology)** - Concept (uses)
   - Theoretical framework describing how individuals encode, store, and retrieve information when confronted with stimulus configurations

5. **Frederic Bartlett** - Other (uses)
   - Pioneering psychologist who first used schema theory in 1932 to explain how people structure and recall perceptual experience

All triples have been successfully validated with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper formatting. The paper is classified as a **survey** since it reviews and discusses existing theoretical work on schema theory and information processing rather than proposing novel methodologies.

- [Recall (memory)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_(memory))
- [Information processing (psychology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_processing_(psychology))
- [Frederic Bartlett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Bartlett)
